title: Impact of climate change on water availability and its propagation through the Western U.S. power grid
excerpt: This paper evaluates how projected changes in water availability affect electricity generation at hydroelectric and thermal power plants and how the coincident impacts propagate locally and throughout the interconnected power grid of western United States

title: The DOE E3SM v1. 1 biogeochemistry configuration: description and simulated ecosystem_climate responses to historical changes in forcing
venue: Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems
excerpt: This paper documents the biogeochemistry configuration of the Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM), E3SMv1.1_BGC. The model simulates historical carbon cycle dynamics, including carbon losses predicted in response to land use and land cover change, and the responses of the carbon cycle to changes in climate

title: Global irrigation characteristics and effects simulated by fully coupled land surface, river, and water management models in E3SM
venue: Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems
excerpt: This paper introduces a two_way coupled irrigation scheme developed within the Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM). The new irrigation scheme simulates irrigation water demand and applies irrigation water in E3SM Land Model (ELM), which is coupled to a river routing model and a water management model (MOSART_WM) that simulate streamflow, reservoir operations, and irrigation water supply

title: The Straightening of a River Meander Leads to Extensive Losses in Flow Complexity and Ecosystem Services
excerpt: This paper was the last chapter of my PhD dissertation. We made a few attempts to publish the work and finally got accepted by Water. This study investigates the meander hydrodynamic changes with regard to the channel curvature

title: Roles of irrigation and reservoir operations in modulating terrestrial water budgets in the Indian sub-continental river basins
excerpt: This paper examines water management impact over Indian basins using VIC-IRR model combined with reservoir scheme

title: The DOE E3SM coupled model version 1: Description and results at high resolution
venue: Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems
excerpt: This paper overviews E3SM V1 at high resolution configuration

title: Flood Inundation Generation Mechanisms and Their Changes in 1953?2004 in Global Major River Basins.
excerpt: This paper used MOSART-inundation to investigate global flood characteristics and the shift of flood generating factors over 50 year period

title: The DOE E3SM Coupled Model Version 1: Overview and Evaluation at Standard Resolution
venue: Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems
excerpt: This paper overviews E3SM V1 at standard resolution configuration
citation: Golaz, J. C., Caldwell, P. M., Van Roekel, L. P., Petersen, M. R., Tang, Q., Wolfe, J. D., ... & Baldwin, S. A. (2019). The DOE E3SM coupled model version 1: Overview and evaluation at standard resolution. Journal of Advances in Modeling Earth Systems, 11(7), 2089-2129.

title: Strong influence of irrigation on water budget and land surface temperature in Indian sub-continental river basins
excerpt: This paper examines irrigation impacts over Indian basins

title: Modulating factors of hydrologic exchanges in a large-scale river reach: insights from three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics simulations
excerpt: This paper investigates the major control factors of hydrologic exchange in a 7km Columbia River reach

title: Non-stationary hydropower generation projections constrained by environmental and electricity grid operations over the western United States
excerpt: This paper compares process-based model predictions with simple regression results in terms of future hydropower generation

title: Evaluating the functionality and streamflow impacts of explicitly modeling forest?snow interactions and canopy gaps in a distributed hydrologic model
excerpt: This paper examines the effect of forest gaps on snow processes

title: Riverbed hydrologic exchange dynamics in a large regulated river reach
excerpt: This paper examines how upstream dam operations controls downstream hydrologic exchange patterns

title: Sensitivity of regulated flow regime to climate change in the Western United States
excerpt: This paper compares the regulated flow and natural flow patterns in western U.S.

title: Coupling a three-dimensional subsurface flow and transport model with a land surface model to simulate stream-aquifer-land interactions (CP v1.0).
excerpt: This paper is about coupling CLM and PFLOTRAN

title: A New Approach to Quantify Shallow Water Hydrologic Exchanges in a Large Regulated River Reach
excerpt: This paper uses streambed temperature to predict vertical hydrologic exchange rate in Columbia River

title: The contribution of reservoirs to global land surface water storage variations
excerpt: This study investigates human-induced water storage (reservoirs) variation and compares it with natural variations (SWE, soil moisture)

title: Human induced changes in the global water cycle
venue: Terrestrial Water Cycle and Climate Change: Natural and Human-Induced Impacts; Geophysical Monograph 221; 57
excerpt: This is a book chapter for AGU monograph about human impact on land surface water budget

title: Evaluation of real-time satellite precipitation data for global drought monitoring
excerpt: This study evaluates the difference between TRMM-real time (RT) and TRMM-research product (RP)

title: A prototype global drought information system based on multiple land surface models
excerpt: This paper is about a global drought monitoring system based on VIC model

title: Reshaping of the hyporheic zone beneath river restoration structures: flume and hydrodynamic experiments
excerpt: This study quantifies how river restoration structures change surface and hyporheic flow hydrodynamics

title: Meander hydrodynamics initiated by river restoration deflectors
excerpt: This study quantifies how river restoration structures change surface flow hydrodynamics
citation: Zhou, T., & Endreny, T. (2012). Meander hydrodynamics initiated by river restoration deflectors. Hydrological Processes, 26(22), 3378-3392.
